books.title: Design as Art
books.author: Bruno Munari
books.notes: Munari's notes on the role of design in everyday life. A classic that challenges you to see design everywhere.
books.summary: Bruno Munari explores the relationship between art and design, arguing that design is an integral part of everyday life. He challenges traditional distinctions between fine art and applied art, showing how good design enhances our daily experiences.
quotes: The designer of today re-establishes the long-lost contact between art and the public.
Design is not just what it looks like and feels like. Design is how it works.
Complicating is easy, simplifying is hard.

books.title: Thinking with Type
books.author: Ellen Lupton
books.notes: My most recommended book on typography for beginners. Essential reading for anyone working with text.
books.summary: A comprehensive guide to typography that covers the history of type, the anatomy of letterforms, and practical techniques for working with text in design.
quotes: Typography is what language looks like.
Typefaces are not inherently legible. Rather, it is the reader's familiarity with faces that accounts for their legibility.

books.title: The Design of Everyday Things
books.author: Don Norman
books.notes: A foundational text on human-centered design. Everyone recommends it for a reason.
books.summary: Don Norman introduces the principles of user-centered design, explaining why some products satisfy customers while others frustrate them. He argues that good design should be intuitive and invisible.
quotes: Design is really an act of communication, which means having a deep understanding of the person with whom the designer is communicating.
The same technology that simplifies life by providing more functions in each device also complicates life by making the device harder to learn.
Good design is actually a lot harder to notice than poor design, in part because good designs fit our needs so well that the design is invisible.

books.title: Interaction of Color
books.author: Josef Albers
books.notes: Color is contextual. This book changed how I think about color relationships.
books.summary: Josef Albers presents his revolutionary approach to color theory through practical exercises and examples. He demonstrates that color perception is relative and influenced by surrounding colors.
quotes: In visual perception a color is almost never seen as it really is.
Colors present themselves in continuous flux, constantly related to changing neighbors and changing conditions.

books.title: A Pattern Language
books.author: Christopher Alexander
books.notes: Perfect for reading random chapters at a time! A peek at various patterns in urban planning & architecture.

books.title: Understanding Comics
books.author: Scott McCloud
books.notes: I recommend this to all designers interested in improving their visual storytelling skills.
books.summary: Scott McCloud explores the medium of comics, breaking down how visual storytelling works. He examines the vocabulary of comics, including panels, gutters, and the relationship between words and images.
quotes: The art form of comics is many centuries old, but it's perceived as a recent invention and suffers the curse of all new media.
Comics is a language. And like any language, it can be used for good or evil.

books.title: Grid Systems in Graphic Design
books.author: Josef MÃ¼ller-Brockmann
books.notes: The go-to book about traditional grids. Essential for understanding systematic design.

books.title: How Buildings Learn
books.author: Stewart Brand
books.notes: What happens after buildings are built? A fascinating look at how structures adapt over time.

books.title: Speculative Everything
books.author: Anthony Dunne & Fiona Raby
books.notes: Conceptual design used to explore potential futures. Mind-expanding.
books.summary: Dunne and Raby propose design as a means of speculating about possible futures, encouraging designers to envision alternative scenarios rather than simply solving immediate problems.
quotes: Design speculations can act as a catalyst for collectively redefining our relationship to reality.

books.title: Visual Explanations
books.author: Edward Tufte
books.notes: Tufte's thoughts on presenting information visually. Trust that the user can process all the information!

books.title: Design is Storytelling
books.author: Ellen Lupton
books.notes: My #1 rec for anyone trying to understand how to think like a designer.

books.title: The Poetics of Space
books.author: Gaston Bachelard
books.notes: A philosophical exploration of intimate spaces. Dreamlike and profound.

books.title: CAPS LOCK
books.author: Ruben Pater
books.notes: How graphic design and capitalism are intertwined. Critical and eye-opening.

books.title: Mismatch
books.author: Kat Holmes
books.notes: How inclusion shapes design. Essential reading on accessibility.

books.title: Race After Technology
books.author: Ruha Benjamin
books.notes: How does technology continue to reinforce racism? Critical tech studies.

books.title: Dear Data
books.author: Giorgia Lupi & Stefanie Posavec
books.notes: A year of hand-drawn data visualizations exchanged as postcards. Beautiful and inspiring.

books.title: The Pragmatic Programmer
books.author: David Thomas & Andrew Hunt
books.notes: The classic guide to becoming a better developer. Timeless advice on craft and pragmatism.

books.title: Don't Make Me Think
books.author: Steve Krug
books.notes: The most accessible introduction to web usability. Short, practical, and timeless.

books.title: Refactoring
books.author: Martin Fowler
books.notes: The definitive guide to improving code structure. Changed how I think about clean code.

books.title: The Mythical Man-Month
books.author: Frederick P. Brooks Jr.
books.notes: Why adding more people to a late project makes it later. Essential reading for tech leads.

books.title: Steal Like an Artist
books.author: Austin Kleon
books.notes: A quick, inspiring read on creativity. Perfect for when you're feeling stuck.

books.title: Sprint
books.author: Jake Knapp
books.notes: How to solve big problems and test ideas in just five days. The Google Ventures method.

books.title: Hooked
books.author: Nir Eyal
books.notes: How to build habit-forming products. Useful framework, but use responsibly.

books.title: Zero to One
books.author: Peter Thiel
books.notes: Contrarian thinking on startups and innovation. Agree or disagree, it's thought-provoking.

books.title: Creative Confidence
books.author: Tom Kelley & David Kelley
books.notes: IDEO founders on unleashing creativity. Everyone is creative, you just need to unlock it.

books.title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
books.author: Daniel Kahneman
books.notes: How we think and make decisions. Dense but fundamental for understanding human behavior.

books.title: The Elements of Style
books.author: William Strunk Jr. & E.B. White
books.notes: The classic guide to clear writing. Short, opinionated, and endlessly useful.

books.title: Atomic Habits
books.author: James Clear
books.notes: Small changes, remarkable results. Practical framework for building better habits.
